description: From the Latin phrase ultra crepidam ("beyond the sandal"). An allusion to the response of the Greek painter Apelles to a cobbler's criticism, as recorded by Pliny the Elder.

verbs.description: ultracrepidate (third-person singular simple present ultracrepidates, present participle ultracrepidating, simple past and past participle ultracrepidated)

entries.meaning: to venture beyond one's competence or purview
examples: The new editor has a lot to learn and should be anxious not to ultracrepidate.
